title: Auckland one-bedroom rental now $400 per week
text:
Auckland one-bedroom rental now $400 per week 
Tuesday 22 Sep 2015 11:14 a.m. 
A one-bedroom unit will now set Auckland renters back $400 a week as landlords respond to exorbitant sale prices and tight supply. 
The city's median asking rents have rocketed up more than eight per cent on a year ago, according to the latest Trade Me Property Rental Price Index released on Tuesday. 
"You're now looking at $499 per week for a typical property, taking annual rent costs close to $26,000 - about $2000 more than a year ago," said the website's property head Nigel Jeffries. 
"It piles more pressure onto the cost of living for tenants." 
An Auckland renter can now expect to pay $400 a week for even the smallest unit or basic one-bedroom house, he said. 
By contrast, the Christchurch rental property market "hit the wall" in March with each month since seeing a decline in asking rent. 
The median asking rent fell five per cent in August to $429 per week. 
Outside these two centres, median asking rent remained relatively stable for the fourth month in a row, up three per cent to $360 per week. 
In Auckland, rents have increased by 28 percent in the past five years, Mr Jeffries said. 
"The first eight months of this year alone have added a whopping $2000 a year to the cost of renting - a hefty price to pay for tenants," he said. 
But a quick glimpse in the city's soaring sales prices for houses puts the rental increases in perspective. 
The average house asking price rose by almost 63 percent in five years, and in the first eight months of 2015 alone, the average asking price rose $80,000 as tight supply continues to drive up prices. 
Other highlights: Rents rose 19 percent in Manawatu/Wanganui in the past year. Rents dropped 14 percent in Gisborne in the past year. Median asking rents in Wellington eased in August to $380 per week, down from a peak in January of $440 per week, unchanged from the same time last year. 
NZN
